quote: I will signal for immediate beam out.
Commander Riker to the bridge.
Damn!
I just woke up, sir.
You know what to do?
No problem. I'll have him out of there as smooth as ice.
Sarjenka, wait!
Do not be afraid. I am Data.
Data. Data, you came.
Data, where have you been?
There is no time for explanations. You and your family must leave.
We already have. We ran when the tremors began.
Then why are you here?
My father wouldn't let us take anything, but I had to have my transmitter. I knew you would come back, and I didn't want you to find only silence -- the way I did.
Yes, well, I am sorry about that, but it is very complicated -- Does your family know where you are?
No.
You cannot survive in this.
What are we going to do?
Enterprise, two to beam up.
Where are we going?
To the stars?
Yes.
There's gonna be hell to pay.
Where is Commander Riker?
On the bridge.
Where are you going?
To the bridge.
You're going to take that?
Leave her here?
Don't leave me here. Please don't leave me.
Quite impossible.
Sir, we are three minutes from resonator launch.
Where is he?
He'll be here.
He has brought that child aboard my ship and onto my bridge.
I'm sure Data will have a very good explanation.
She was frightened and did not want to be left alone
Mister Data, would you kindly assume your station.
Counselor, escort her to Sickbay.
It's all right, nobody's going to hurt you.
We'll go and get a treat, and --
NO!
Captain, I will not allow her to be in the way.
Two minutes to resonator launch.
Little one, hush, it's all right.
(interrupting, very shrill) NO! Leave me alone! I want Data!
Counselor, allow me. Please.
Hush, it is all right now. No one will harm you. These are my friends.
Take your station, Mister Data, and keep her with you. This does directly concern her.
Thirty seconds to resonator launch.
I require my hand now.
Firing torpedoes.
Sensors locked on probes.
Torpedos have reached their targets...
Resonators activated. Harmonic sequences have begun.
What are you doing?
We are attempting to quiet your planet. If we succeed, there will be no more quakes, no more volcanos.
When should the results become evident?
Very quickly, sir.
And my parents and brothers?
If our experiment...
They will soon be safe.
Captain, sensors indicate a planetwide reduction in tectonic stress levels.
It's working. We did it!
You did this for me?
Sarjenka, look.
Starboard view.
There, there are your stars.
What are you thinking?
Someday, I'm going to be here.
Data, take Sarjenka to Sickbay.
Sir, must we?
Yes.
Data and the alien are on their way down. What would be involved in removing all memory of her communication with Data and her visit to this ship?

Assuming her brain structure is similar to ours the memories will be stored chemically on the neurons of the cerebral cortex. They are also time dependent. I'll have to scan for age of the chemical links, and try to find the relevant neurons. To be sure I may have to go back weeks before the initial contact with Data.
Well, do your best.
You have many different kinds of people here.
Yes.
When I'm bigger can I be on your ship?
I am certain you could.
I wish I could come with you now.
There are many things in life which we desire but will never receive. This is one of them.
I know, but I can still wish for it.
Sarjenka, this is Doctor Pulaski.
Hello, dear.
Hello.
What is this?
An Elanin Singer Stone. It sings a different song for each person.
What does it sing for you?
It does not sing for me.
Why not?
Because I am a machine.
Oh Data, I'm sorry.
Sarjenka, we're going to run a few scans just to make sure you're all right.
Data's going to be right with you. Don't worry.
You did a good thing, Data.
But are we doing a good thing now?
Data, this is to protect her as much as us.
By robbing her of her memories?
To remember you and this ship would complicate her future. She has to be the person she was born to be. And you'll remember.
Sit down.
No thank you sir. It's going to be a long time before I'm really qualified to sit here.
You did a good job, Wes. I'm proud of you.
Thank you, sir.
Does it get any easier?
No.
Come.
I came to thank you.
No thanks are necessary. You reminded us that there are obligations beyond duty.
You did not have to hold that conference. Your decision could have been unilateral.
One of my officers...
... One of my friends was in trouble. I had to help him.
I am going to miss her, Captain.
That too is part of friendship, remembrance and regrets.
Yes, sir.
And understanding that has taken you a step closer to humanity.
Marking beam-out position. Return transport: fourteen minutes, forty seconds.
Your view any better, Geordi?
Not too bad, sir. A lot of charged-particle precipitation, but I can compensate.
Communicators are dysfunctional.
Tricorders?
Readings only valid within five meters.
I'm not so sure of that... I'm reading Worf as an unintelligent life form.
Good thing we didn't bring Data... we would've been unscrambling his circuits for a week...
Picking up something on the positron scan, Commander.
Over here. Some electrically conductive objects.
Recognize the markings, Worf?
Yessir. Romulan.
I wonder what the hell they were doing in a Federation sector.
I'm picking up traces of ultritium residue with my VISOR, Commander. An explosive device must've been used to destroy the craft after it crashed.
Spread out... twenty five meter radius... our window back closes in nine minutes...
Commander...
Commander Riker...
COMMANDER RIKER... WORF... HEY UP THERE...
Four minutes to beam-up, sir.
Where is he? Wait here...
La Forge to Riker... La Forge to Worf... HEY...
GEORDI...
Lieutenant Worf, maintain your position.
Captain's log, Stardate 43349.2. An unidentified distress signal has led to the discovery of a crashed Romulan vessel on the surface of Galorndon Core, a Federation planet.
We have recovered one survivor. Lieutenant Commander La Forge did not report back with the away team and is still missing on the surface.
Get him to Sickbay.
Secure Sickbay. Post guards in visual contact at all times.
He's not going anywhere, Lieutenant.
I'm sorry, Commander... There's just no way to lock in on anything down there...
Keep trying, Mister O'Brien.
(shakes his head, useless) The electrical storms are creating thousands of ghosts...
Then beam some of the ghosts up here... one of them may be La Forge. Request permission to lead another away team...
Denied. When we get another window in the storms.
The crash site?
The Romulan craft's a total loss. There's nothing there to salvage -- unless we do it with tweezers.
No sign of others...
We could barely see two meters in front of us down there...
It certainly is the last place one would expect a Romulan encroachment. On the other hand, Galorndon Core would provide ideal cover for an opening move of a new offensive.
I doubt they were there for the climate.
We thought it would be like working on a Vulcan, but there are subtle differences... too many of them...
Can you treat him?
He has cell damage in vital areas... He's going to need a transfusion of compatible ribosomes in order to recover. I'm setting up a schedule to test every member of the crew.
Will he survive?
I can't answer that yet.
Let me put it another way -- will he survive long enough to tell us what he was doing here?
It is an important consideration, Doctor.
I can't put his life in any additional jeopardy...
Nor would we ask you to.
I can bring him around for a few minutes...
There is one serious complication. His brainwaves indicate early neural-pathway degeneration.
A head injury?
There was no obvious cranial trauma. I'm guessing the exposure to the magnetic fields on the surface was slowly breaking down his synaptic connections.
Will it affect Geordi the same way?
You are aboard the Federation Starship Enterprise. We are treating your injuries. How long were you on Galorndon Core? Do you understand me?
I will not answer questions.
We must know if there are any other survivors on the surface.
I am alone. I will not answer any questions.
Is there a mother ship we should advise of your condition?
The only answer he offers is that he was alone...
... which suggests he wasn't.
Something that can cut through the storm... to give us some way to signal him...
A neutrino pulse...
We could build a portable neutrino source and send it in a probe to the surface. It would be like a beacon.
A neutrino pulse would send non-charged particles back up through the atmosphere... and would be detectable by Geordi's VISOR.
He'll be able to show us that he's found it by modifying the pulse...
Make it so.
Captain, I have a new transmission on a parallel frequency to the distress call...
From the planet?
No sir... from inside the Romulan Zone. We should be able to view the transmission.
On screen.
Tomalak to Pi. We have received your distress signal. Respond. If you can hear me, we are entering the Neutral Zone now... We will reach you in six hours.
Mister Worf, hail the Romulan vessel.
Frequency open, sir.
Romulan vessel. This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Federation Starship Enterprise.
The frequency is open, sir.
Commander Tomalak, we have intercepted your transmission. You are not to enter Federation space.
Captain Picard, my apologies. If I had known you were in this sector, I certainly would have advised you before crossing the Neutral Zone.
Really...
I'm sure you'll understand when I explain. Simply, one of our ships had a slight navigational error and apparently crashed on Galorndon Core.
A "slight" navigational error. Nearly half a light year past the Neutral Zone.
I assure you, Captain, no aggression was intended.
Commander, we have recovered one of your survivors.
He is on board your ship?
We are treating him for severe injuries.
And his craft?
Destroyed... deliberately... after the crash.
Standard procedure for all Romulan crews.
For all Romulan crews in enemy space... which would suggest they knew where they were, Commander.
If I were lost and uncertain, I would not take any chances. Nor I suspect would you, Captain. May I speak to him?
He is not conscious... and not well enough to leave Sickbay.
Captain, with your permission...
I am Doctor Crusher, the medical officer. We are doing everything we can for him and it still may not be enough. Any medical guidance your ship's doctor can offer...
My dear, there is no way to talk you through the intricacies of Romulan medicine. His life is in your hands.
I assume that you are prepared to leave at once and rendezvous with me in the Neutral Zone.
I have an away team on the surface. We are waiting for a window in the storm to beam them back.
And then you will return my officer?
Are there any other Romulans we should be looking to recover from Galorndon Core... ?
No. It was a one-man craft. Captain, we will be at the Federation border of the Neutral Zone in roughly five hours. We will expect you to rendezvous at that time.
Counselor?
There is great hostility behind his smile, Captain. To complete his mission, he will stop at nothing.
Including the Neutral Zone border?
Sir, I see no reason to return the Romulan to his ship. He should be held and interrogated.
We do have a right to detain him, Captain.
Without clear evidence of intent, it would not be a simple matter.
This was obviously not pilot's error, Captain... it requires a response from us.
We must measure the response carefully, Number One. Or history may remember Galorndon Core alongside Pearl Harbor and Station Salem-One... as the stage for a bloody preamble to war.
What the hell... ?
About five degrees off... huh. The water maybe... ?
I want him off all the drugs... they aren't doing anything... Doctor Crusher to Picard.
Go ahead.
My patient is not responding to treatment.
You haven't found a compatible ribosome donor?
The lab is still processing the tests... early results indicate humans have far too many biorejection factors. I've also ruled out the Vulcans we've tested.
We'll try a little old-fashioned country medicine... keep the fever down, try to let the body heal itself...
Keep me advised. Picard out.
Captain, the neutrino beacon is operational. We've placed it aboard a class three probe.
Well done, Ensign. Launch the probe.
Probe has entered the atmosphere, sir.
The neutrino stream is coming in strongly. Sensors are tracking the probe despite the interference.
This better not be another malfunction...
A stationary neutrino source...
Wesley Crusher.
You are my prisoner.
Right. Congratulations. Certainly, a strategic triumph for the Romulan Empire.
Stay there.
My shoes are getting full of sand... I just hate that, don't you? You think we could just maybe move outta the...
How many other Federation troops are with you?
We just stopped by to rescue you, big fella... which I'm still willing to do if you'll put that down...
Or we can just stand here and take in the view...
Your name and rank.
Lieutenant Commander Geordi La Forge. I don't believe I caught yours... ?
A Romulan ship will arrive shortly... you will accompany me on board...

Uh, I really don't think that's gonna happen, Ensign... or is it Commodore... (a beat, Bochra doesn't react) Yeah, see... we heard your message too... and well, the fleet's in, Commodore. Sky's full of Federation ships.
You're lying.
I never lie when I've got sand in my shoes, Commodore.
Get up.
Seriously. There's only one way out of here. Put that down and I'll take you back to my ship as soon as there's a window in the storm...
You gotta be kidding.
Sit.
Welcome to Galorndon Core, where no good deed goes unpunished...
Yes, Doctor...
Lieutenant. Good. Come in. Please, sit down...
We've finally found a compatible ribosome match for the Romulan. But only one. You.
That is impossible. I am a Klingon.

Different species, yes. But Humans, Romulans, Vulcans, Klingons, Betazoids -- we're all genetically similar. We have comparable cell structures. And you have what this Romulan needs. There's absolutely no risk to you...
You did understand that was the purpose of all the testing...
I have no objection to tests.
You have an objection to being a donor.
Yes.
Lieutenant, I understand your feelings about the Romulans. But this is not the time or place...
If you had seen them kill your parents, you would understand, Doctor. It is always the time and place for those feelings.
This Romulan did not kill your parents. And you are the only one who can save his life.
Then he will die.
I don't need him to like the idea, Captain... just to do it.
There is no alternative?
The alternative is the Romulan will die. Worf is quite correct on that point.
We need him alive... It is easy to forget that our Lieutenant Worf is not human. His values are very different from yours and mine.
Of course they are. But he is also an officer of Starfleet... and this is...
... this is a personal matter...
It's very personal, Captain. Especially to the Romulan who's dying in my Sickbay. Maybe he has a family waiting for him to come home.
Worf is a good man. I know with a word of encouragement from you he will do the right thing.
Order him.
Encourage him.
A captain's encouragement is difficult to refuse, Doctor. And difficult to offer to a man whose feelings run so deep.
Even if it means the life of the Romulan?
I must respect his personal views... even if I do not share them. He will have to live with the consequences of his decision.
We will all have to.
I wish you'd put that away.
You're afraid of dying.
You bet I am. Who isn't?
I'm not.
Right.
To die in the service of my people...
Ah, the Romulan path to glory.
You can be sarcastic -- now. But in a few millennia, when humans are extinct and the Romulan Empire spans the galaxy...
You really believe that stuff, don't you, Commodore?
Our culture is far older and wiser than yours. It's inevitable that we will prevail.
Well, if you're that sure of yourselves, why be so tight-lipped? You won't even tell me your name.
I see no need to tell you.
Why? Is it a military secret or something? I've told you mine. Okay, Commodore... whatever you say.
You may address me as Centurion Bochra.
Ahh. Bochra. Good, solid Romulan name. And you're a centurion. Well, stay with it, you'll be a commodore someday.
I'm not certain of the equivalent Federation rank... but I do know it's higher than lieutenant commander.
What's the matter?
Nothing.
Wrong. Your heart rate just shot way up.
It translates a wide range of radiation into neural impulses. Allows me to see.
Without it, you are blind?
Yes...
How did this happen?
I was born that way.
(honestly doesn't understand) And your parents let you live?
What kind of question is that? Of course they let me live.
No wonder your race is weak. You waste time and resources on defective children...
Defective? Listen, Commodore -- I'm a chief engineer in Starfleet. You don't get there by being defective.
But if you can't see...
I can see things you can't even imagine.
Whoa...
I'm having some sort of polarity shift. The diagnostic insists everything's fine...
Your body temperature's gone up another full degree...
What are you saying?
It's this place... All that electromagnetic soup is playing hell with our nervous systems. Your metabolism's messed up... so's my interface with the VISOR.
We've got to get out of here while we still can.
Sit down.
Bochra...
Sit down.
What's that?
Just a background fluctuation, Commander... he hasn't found it yet.
Then he must be hurt... or dead. How long before another window, Data?
There are none indicated, Commander. I have no way to predict.
Incoming Romulan transmission, Captain.
They're early.
The Romulan warbird should still be twenty-nine minutes away from the edge of the Neutral Zone.
Close enough, however, to see we're not there. On screen.
Picard, I'm approaching the Federation border and the Enterprise is not to be found. Why?
My away team has not been able to leave the surface because of the storms.
And my officer?
He is alive.
His life remains in jeopardy?
Yes.
And yet you will still not permit me to cross into your precious Federation space to retrieve him...
If the point hasn't been made clearly, Commander, let me make it again.
Romulan warships do not enter Federation space unless they are prepared to do battle.
But a mission of mercy...
A mission to recover one of your officers who was caught on a Federation planet. For reasons still unknown...
I have already explained that.
And I have rejected your explanation.
Territories... you would measure territories against a man's life?
Commander, your singular concern for a life is impressive. Do not risk any more lives by leaving the Neutral Zone. Picard out.
Bochra, you're in bad shape.
My vision's getting worse. There's a beacon out there... it'll get us back to my ship... but not if I can't find it.
I can't surrender to the Federation.
Then stay here and die.
If the situation were reversed... would you not die to avoid capture?
I don't know. I might... if I thought it was necessary. If the stakes were high enough. But they'd have to be pretty damn high.
Guess I'd make a pretty lousy Romulan, huh... ?
I no more wish to die than you do.
You mean Romulans aren't always ready to sacrifice themselves on command?
No more than humans are frail, weak-willed children without any conception of loyalty or duty.
Bochra -- there are times when dying for one's ideals is necessary. Do you believe this is one of those times?
Let's find that beacon.
What is it?
Everything's gone blank. I'm blind.
Come.
You are busy. Forgive my intrusion.
For what it's worth, I understand your bitterness.
With respect, sir... you cannot. I am asked to give up the very lifeblood of my mother, of my father, to those who murdered them.
Must you blame all Romulans for that?
Yes.
Forever, Worf? What if the Federation should make peace with the Romulans someday...
Impossible.
Not long ago, your people said the same thing about humans.

And so many on both sides died in that war. How could you and I be here now... like this... if we were unable to let go of the anger, the blame. When does it end, Worf? If the Romulan dies, does his family carry the bitterness forward another generation?
Then you believe I should.
What I believe doesn't matter.
My Starfleet training tells me one thing. Everything I am tells me another.
Lieutenant Worf, report to Sickbay.
Acknowledged.
Lieutenant, his life is coming to an end. I thought it important for you to see him again.
It is not too late to change your mind.
Come close to me, Klingon. Let me die with my hands at your throat.
I am the only one who can keep you alive.
You?
There is a substance within my cells which you need to survive...
You have come to hear me beg for my life.
No.
I would rather die than pollute my body with Klingon filth.
I have lost almost all feeling in my legs.
My synapses must be turning to jelly. The VISOR's fine, but I can't see a thing.
How do we locate the beacon?
We don't.
Do all humans give up so easily?
Are all Romulans so pushy? Bochra, we're lost... unless you've got something that can smell neutrinos.
We have the sensor device you were carrying.
My tricorder? It isn't set up to detect neutrinos.
But your eye device does. Connect them.

That's crazy. They don't speak the same language. I'd never get an accurate sampling... (stops; maybe it's not so crazy) But, then, I don't need an accurate sampling. I just need a pointer... a neutrino Geiger counter.
Still not possible.
You cannot do it?
Under normal circumstances, maybe. Here, no way.
Why?
Because I can't see. Adapting the neural output pods of the VISOR is tricky work. It can't be done by "touch."
Then I'll be your eyes.
The storm is beginning to subside, Captain... we should have a window in less than an hour...
Still no indication he's found the beacon, sir...
Assemble an away team...
Yes, sir...
Captain... the Romulan warship has crossed the Neutral Zone border. It is in Federation space and heading toward us.
Stand by, Number One. Red Alert.
... make sure the scan select limiter matches the VISOR output range.
Not so fast...
Done.
Now close the case and place the neural output pods in contact with the tricorder scanner heads.
Ready.
Let her rip.
Bearing three-five-zero.
We did it! The first Federation-Romulan co-venture.
The storm may be breaking.
With any luck an electromagnetic window will be opening up and we can get out of here.
At which point I'll be your prisoner.
Can you walk?
I don't know...
Straight ahead...
You wished to see me, Captain.
Yes, Lieutenant. I assume you know what this is about...

The Romulan ship will reach us within the hour, Lieutenant. If our patient dies... it may be just the excuse the Romulan commander needs to start an incident. The death of a Romulan officer at the hands of the Federation! Think of it.
I have, Captain.
There is no question that this Romulan is more valuable to us alive than dead, Lieutenant.
I understand.

Sometimes the moral obligations of command are less than clear. I weigh the good of the many against the needs of the individual... and try to balance them as realistically as possible. God knows I don't always succeed.
I have not had cause to complain, Captain.
You wouldn't complain even if you had cause, Lieutenant.
If you order me to agree to the transfusion, I will, of course, obey.
I cannot order you. I will not order you, Lieutenant. But I ask you. I beg you to volunteer.
I cannot, Captain.
Lieutenant...
Sir?
Dismissed.
Picard to Doctor Crusher.
Go ahead.
Do not continue to enlist Lieutenant Worf's assistance.
I won't have to, Captain. The Romulan has died.
We've found it.
Now we have to change its signal pattern so the Enterprise knows we've found it.
Will that be difficult?
Not with your help.
Scanners show a window, Captain.
Estimated duration?
Nine minutes, forty seconds.
No change in the neutrino beacon signal, sir.
Romulan ship approaching. Bearing three-fifty-four mark two-eight-seven.
On screen.
Romulan is entering phaser range.
We are being hailed, sir.
On screen.
You have one chance to escape destruction, Picard. Return my officer at once.
You have entered Federation space despite my warning, Commander.
You forced this situation. I will not leave without him.
He is dead.
Then he is but the first to fall, Picard.
The Romulan ship is routing power to its forward disruptor array.
All shields to maximum.
Aye, sir.
Lock phasers on target.
Phasers locked and ready.
Captain -- the signal pattern from the neutrino beacon is modulating.
Geordi!
We can't transport him with our shields up.
If we lower our shields, the Romulan will strike.
The electromagnetic window on the planet is closing. Three minutes remain.
Transporter Room. Lock onto the coordinates of the neutrino beacon and stand by.
Standing by, Captain.
Captain, the window is allowing intermittant sensor readings... There are still numerous ghost images, but I believe we are picking up two life forms near the beacon...
Another Romulan?
I cannot say. The electromagnetic interference prevents an accurate reading.
But it is a likely hypothesis, Number One. If Mister La Forge located a second survivor... Hail the Romulan ship, Lieutenant.
Aye, sir. They're ignoring our hail, sir.
Repeat the hail -- all channels. He has no way of knowing how accurate our sensors are... put on your poker face, Number One... Open frequency.
Commander Tomalak. It would appear our away team has rescued a second man from your one man ship.
They are on the surface, ready to beam up. We are preparing to do so. After which we will return the survivor to you.
No acknowledgement, Captain.

Commander, both our ships are ready to fight. We have two supremely powerful, destructive arsenals at our command. Our next actions will have serious repercussions for both sides. We have good reason to mistrust one another, Commander, but we have better reasons to set our differences aside. The question, of course, is who will show vulnerability first. The answer is -- I will. I must lower my shields to transport these men off the planet surface.

Once the shields are down, you will have an opportunity to open fire. If you do, you will not only destroy the Enterprise and its crew -- but also the cease-fire that the Romulans and the Federation now enjoy.
Lieutenant, lower the shields. Leave hailing frequencies open.
Yes, sir.
Mister O'Brien. Transport Mister La Forge and the Romulan directly to the bridge.
Aye, sir. Energizing.
Security team to bridge.
Belay that order, Lieutenant. Shields up. No one is going to harm you.
You have my word.
Well, Commander?
If he has been in any way mistreated...
I have given them no information, Commander -- but I have not been mistreated. In fact, this human saved my life.
Commander, how is it possible you didn't know of this second Romulan on Galorndon Core?
A simple misunderstanding, Captain Picard. I was obviously misinformed as to the size of the craft. I assure you, I intended no deception.
Of course not.
You doubt my good faith?
Let's just say my faith would be strengthened with a gesture -- such as powering down your disruptors.
Disruptors powering down, Captain.
Thank you. Cancel Red Alert, Lieutenant.
We will return your officer and escort your ship back to the Neutral Zone, Commander.
That is acceptable.
Mister La Forge, it's good to have you back.
I have Centurion Bochra to thank, sir.
Your vision is returning...
Yeah, gradually. Your heart rate's slowing down.
Mister La Forge, Mister Worf -- escort our guest to Transporter Room One.
Aye, sir.
Close call.
Too close, Number One. Brinksmanship is a dangerous game...
It was not in my power to save him.
He was a loyal officer.
Lieutenant Commander La Forge.
Centurion Bochra.
You're not what I expected of a Federation officer.
That's okay; you're not what I expected of a Romulan, either. That's a compliment.
That's the way to fight all the wars from now on. Two guys on a planet with no one else to talk to and nowhere to go. Things get settled in a hurry.
I'm gonna sleep for four days...
I don't want any trouble, Barlcay...
Trouble? Why would there be trouble?
There's always trouble when you come in here.
You're on duty, Lieutenant.
Is that a fact?
It is, and you'll observe it. Get back to your post.
Look, pal. Do me a favor. Take yourself and your holier-than-thou attitude and get out of my life.
This is insubordination, Mister Barclay.
So punish me.
Security to Ten-Forward!
"Insubordination."
Riker, you're nothing but a pretty mannequin dressed up in a fancy uniform. You're full of hot air, and if Picard has a problem with me, he can come and tell me himself...
I feel your confidence, your arrogant resolve. It excites me.
Lieutenant Barclay, report to Cargo Bay Five now.
This will have to wait, darling. Um... Be right there. Freeze program. Exit.
Save program.
I just don't know what to do with him. He's always late, never gives his best effort, always slides by... I can't deal with it anymore. How does a guy like him ever make it through the Academy...
I think it's time we talked to the captain about Broccoli. That's what Wesley calls him. Keep it to yourself.
It fits.
A broken seal, Commander.
You better destroy it. Those samples will be tainted.
Is it a problem for you to report to duty on time, Lieutenant?
Problem? Nossir. I'm... I'm very sorry, sir... it's just... I had a very important communique... it required my immediate response and...
I don't want to hear it... we're having intermittent problems with the anti-grav unit, see what you can do...
Mister Barclay, I'm tired of seeing your name on report. I don't know what you got away with on your last posting, but this is the Enterprise. We set a different standard here. Understood?
Understood... sir.

Captain's log, Stardate 43807.4. We are taking on a load of special tissue samples donated by the Mikulaks for shipment to Nahmi Four. The samples could prove vital to the containment of an outbreak of Correllium Fever on that world.
Everything looks... it looks normal to me...
Dammit..
I... I don't understand...
La Forge to Engineering... I'll need more people in Cargo Bay Five... anyone you can spare. Out.
We could use a hand, Mister Barclay...
I'll... I'll disassemble it later, Commander... it shouldn't do that... well, of course, it shouldn't do that... I mean... well, it shouldn't do that.
I'm not accustomed to seeing an unsatisfactory rating for one of my crew.
I guess the issue is whether Mister Barclay is Enterprise material.
I assume from your request for his transfer that you don't think he is, Commander...
I hate to say it... I always thought I could work with anyone... but I just can't stand the guy. Broccoli makes me nervous... he makes everyone nervous...
Broccoli?
Young Mister Crusher started it. I'm afraid it's caught on.
Let's get it uncaught, shall we?

By all indications, Barclay has served honorably in Starfleet for many years. His rating aboard the Zhukov was satisfactory... I recall Captain Gleason speaking quite highly of him before his transfer...
In retrospect, I wonder if Captain Gleason wasn't buttering our bread a little...
He knew we were looking for a diagnostic engineer.
I've reviewed Barclay's psychological profile. He's always had seclusive tendencies... it was noted at the Academy more than once...
And yet he chose this way of life; he's made the same commitment to Starfleet that we all have... It's easy to transfer our problem to someone else. Too easy.
Captain, it's not like I haven't tried...
Try harder.
He's on your team. Manage him. Pull him in. Find ways to help him make a positive contribution. Get to know the man. Make him your best friend.
With all respect, sir... my best friend? I can barely tolerate being in the same room with the man...
I suggest you put your personal discomfort with him aside, Commander. Dismissed.
My best friend.
Hey, Reg...
Uh, how's it going?
Oh, it's... I still haven't traced the problem, Commander...
That's okay. No rush. Take your time.
I've... I've been planning to run diagnostics on the graviton invertor circuits...
Smart plan... well, I'd say we're in good hands here...
I'll get a preliminary report to you...
...whenever.
Before the end of the day.
Fine. And say, Reg, how about sitting in on the mission briefing with my senior officers in the morning...
The briefing? Me?
I'd just like your input...
On what? I mean, should I prepare something...
No... no... just be there. Eight hundred hours.
I'll be on time, sir.
Good.
Morning. Start your brains, and let's do it.

(points to injectors on schematic) Okay, this trip to Nahmi Four is pretty routine. We'll have plenty of time to realign the magnetic capacitors in both the matter and anti-matter injectors. Duffy, Costa, that'll be your assignment.
We probably ought to do the flow regulator maintenance at the same time, Commander.

Good idea. Ensign Crusher is putting in some hours with us this week as part of his training duties... he'll be assigned to assist you, Mister Myers. Be sure and teach him the difference between impulse and warp drive. Lieutenant Barclay is working on the mystery of the anti-grav failure we had yesterday... your preliminary report had a couple of interesting theories, Reg...
Why don't you summarize your findings so far, Reg...
Yes. It wasn't a maintenance problem... everything checked out. I... I'm going to check for... a surge in... the transfer coils.
A coil surge wouldn't have resulted in a field dissipation.
I... I... I realize that...
(trying to rescue the the situation) But we shouldn't ignore the possibility, Wes...
You ought to take a look at the flow capacitor. That could have forced a chain collapse of the antigrav field.
I... was going to.
Good. Okay, then... let's go over the realignment procedure...
I just didn't know what to say.
What do you wish you had said?
I should have told him to mind his own damned business... I knew about the flow capacitor... I didn't need to hear about it from a seventeen year old kid.
You're letting it get you much too upset.
You think so?
Why are you so hard on yourself?
You don't know... it's hard out there.
I understand, but let go of it. You're here now.
You're right, of course.
Of course.
Let me help you relax.
I'd like that.
I knew you would.
Mmm, nice... but I'm in the mood for someplace a little more... unusual... Computer. Run Barclay Program Fifteen.
I am the Goddess of Empathy. Cast off your inhibitions and embrace love, truth, joy...
But I thought that's the point of the briefing... to discuss different approaches...
I'm not saying you did anything wrong, Wes... it's just that Barclay's... well, my new project.
Yeah, Broccoli's a real project all right...
I just gotta draw him out more...
And I shut him down. Poor Broccoli.
Pardon me, but why is Lieutenant Barclay being referred to clandestinely as a vegetable?
It's a joke, Data... you know, a nickname.
Nicknames generally denote fondness, a diminutive shared between friends. This does not sound friendly.
Data's absolutely right. The nickname stops here and now. Captain's orders.
What the hell... ?
What happened to your glass?
Nucleo-synthesis. The structure of the glass has been altered at the atomic level.
A problem with the replicator?

Unlikely. A problem with the replicator would have affected the contents as well as the glass. But the liquid in the glass was a perfect replication of a dark ale of Earth origin which I believe is what Lieutenant Duffy ordered.
I can't detect any residual radiation or unusual chemical compounds that would have caused this.
The most probable explanation is that the glass came into contact with an unshielded power source.
That means a complete diagnostic check of the Enterprise power systems. All four thousand of them.
Have I got the man for this job... Hey, Reg...
Busy?
Well, I was just... no, not really... what?
Got another mystery for you... somehow the molecular structure of this cup from Ten-Forward has been altered...
Mister Barclay is the Sherlock Holmes of the technical support crew...
A fascinating vocation, Mister Barclay. I am a student of Sherlock Holmes mysteries and I would enjoy discussing some of your cases at your leisure.
My cases... ?
(to Barclay, indicating glass) Uh, Reg, we're gonna have to run through the power systems, to see if there's some kind of leak that caused this.
I had to... I was going to do it anyway...
You were?
To... to try and explain the anti-grav unit failure... I still can't... nothing about it makes sense.
Then it is possible these two very disparate incidents could be related.
I wouldn't bother you with something this minor, Commander... but it may be a symptom of a more serious problem...
You think we'll need to put in to a starbase?
We'll have a better idea after Mister Barclay runs a check of the power systems...
It was Lieutenant Barclay who first suggested the link between the two incidents, sir.
No, it wasn't. Not really.
Will your investigation affect our available power during the mission, Lieutenant?
No... nossir... we'll have to shut off some systems... they'll be down a few at a time... it shouldn't... I don't think so.
Good. I look forward to your report, Mister Broccoli.
Barclay.
If you'll excuse me.
Metathesis is one of the most common of pronunciation errors, sir... a reversal of vowel and consonant, "bark" to "broc"...
Yes, I know him... comes in here, stands at the bar, doesn't say much... always orders a warm milk.
Figures.
Warm milk helps you sleep, La Forge. You should try it. What's that got to do with Barclay?
I don't know. I'm just trying to figure the man out, that's all. You ever talk to him?
He's not much for talking.
Does he have any friends?
Not that I've seen.
What do you do with a guy like that?
I give him his warm milk and let him be.
Yeah, well, I'm not so lucky. I can't let him be. He's my problem.
He's imaginative.
How do you know that?
I just do.
Well, then maybe he's in the wrong line of work.
You engineering types don't appreciate imagination... ?
That's not it, Guinan... he just doesn't fit in here...
Terkim.
What?
Reminds me of Terkim. My mother's brother. A kind of family misfit. Everybody told me to stay away from him. Bad influence.
Did you?

Are you kidding? He was the only member of the family with a sense of humor. But no one ever stayed around him long enough to realize it... except me. My mother says I take after him. I probably do. Because the idea of "fitting in" repels me, too.
Maybe I didn't make myself clear... Barclay, he's always late... he's nervous... nobody wants to be around him...
If I had the feeling that nobody wanted to be around me, I'd probably be late and nervous too.
Guinan, that's not the point...
Are you sure?
I'll take another one of these.
Get it yourself.
Computer, where is Lieutenant Barclay?
Reg... ?
Beverly?
Good morning, Mi-lord. Manners, my son. Manners. You embarrass me before our guest.
Master Barclay will spank you if you don't behave.
I don't care.
Wesley... ?
What do you want?
Ah, well, I guess I want... Master Barclay.
The boys got into another little scrap, I'm afraid. But boys will be boys.
You cannot withstand our assault forever, Barclay.
Say you will yield and it ends here...
I will speak with my sword, sir...
Where in God's name did you learn to fight like this, man?
Self-taught, my good capitaine. Shall I give you a few lessons?
Who is that? One of your allies?
Jean-Luc. Not that old trick. I'm disappointed in you.
I'll... I'll make it easy for you, Commander. I'll just request reassignment...
Now, wait a minute...
Look, we both know... the whole ship knows... I can't cut it here.
Hey, Barclay... I've spent a few hours in the Holodeck myself, you know.
Far as I'm concerned... what you do in the Holodeck is your own business... as long as it doesn't affect your work.
You're... you're not going to tell anyone about this?
I'm not sure everyone would appreciate your... imagination... like I do.
It is kind of unusual... recreating people you already know...
I was just kind of really... well, it was just... I needed to blow off some steam... because one... one of the officers had been on my back...
Let me guess...
Okay, it was you. And I couldn't tell you what I wanted to, to your face... and it just sort of... I guess it got out of control.
I don't know... sounds like maybe there's a side to this that's kind of therapeutic... we ought to tell Counselor Troi about it.
It's... it's just more comfortable... when I'm in there. You don't know what a struggle it is for me, Commander.
I'd like to help if I can.
(shakes his head, you can't) Being afraid all the time that I'll forget somebody's name. Or not knowing what to do with my hands...

I mean, I'm the guy who writes down things to remember to say when there's a party. And when I get there, I'll wind up alone in a corner trying to look comfortable examining a potted plant. Sometimes, I just don't want to get out of bed in the morning.
Sometimes, neither do I.
No, but you're good. You were born to be in Starfleet. Me...
You're just shy, Barclay.
"Just shy"... sounds like nothing serious, doesn't it... You can't know.
O'Brien to La Forge.
Go ahead.
I need you in Transporter Room Three, Commander.
On my way, Chief.
I really do want you to talk to Counselor Troi, Reg.
Troi? No, no, I couldn't.
I mean it. As your friend and as your commanding officer.
I was synchronizing the phase transition coils... I didn't do anything I haven't done a hundred times before...
The test object is made of pure duranium.
Seems normal enough...
Watch this...
I'm glad I don't have anywhere to go. FADE OUT. END OF ACT TWO
Chief engineer's log, Stardate 43808.2. A systems analysis of Transporter Room Three has yielded no suggestion of a cause for the latest malfunction aboard the Enterprise.
Is this part of the same pattern?
We don't know, Captain. And we don't know why only Transporter Room Three is affected... None of the other Transporter Rooms are malfunctioning...
Yet.
We have twenty-two hours before we reach Nahmi Four. We'll need the transporters operational by then. I want a level one diagnostic across the board.
(acknowledges, to Geordi) Advise Mister Barclay to meet us on the bridge immediately...
Ah, could we push that back, just to fourteen hundred hours, Commander... I've got him doing something...
Fourteen hundred hours. Mister O'Brien, no maintenance on the Transporters until further notice.
Aye, sir.
I can tell this is difficult for you.
Is there anything I can do to make you more comfortable?
No!
Have you ever been with a counselor before?
Yes. No.
Which one?
Yes. But she... it wasn't real... really a counselor.
Most people find a counselor intimidating at first. It's okay if you feel that way toward me.
Not... at all.
Good. Close your eyes... Lean back.
Why?
I just want to help you relax.
You do?
Put your feet up... it's okay. And close your eyes...
What are you going to do?
Just listen to the sound of my voice...
Take a slow deep breath through your nose... and let it out through your mouth just as slowly... good... there, that's better, isn't it...
Oh, yes. Oh, yes, much better. This has been... extremely helpful... Well, thank-you for your time.
But...
Really... very helpful... in through the nose, out through the mouth... I'll practice and let you know... thank you again...
I had a very strange visit from one of your officers today.
Barclay. Yes, I can imagine. Were you able to do anything for him?
To be honest, I'm not exactly sure what happened...
(entering from Picard's Ready Room) Where is Mister Barclay... it's past fourteen hundred hours...
Lieutenant Barclay to the bridge. Lieutenant Barclay report.
Computer. Locate Lieutenant Barclay.
Lieutenant Barclay is in Holodeck Two.
I'll get him...
No, I'll handle this. I've had it with him.
Counselor, you better come along...
I think you should know that Barclay's been running some... unique programs.
I don't care what he's been running. My patience just ran out.
Like I said Commander, Barclay's been running some... unusual programs.
This is a violation of protocol. Crewmembers should not be simulated in the Holodeck...
Ah, Commander... I don't think there's any regulation...
Then there should be... computer, discontinue program and erase...
Computer, belay that order!
Counselor...
If Barclay is having a difficult time facing reality, to suddenly destroy his only means of escape would be brutal and could do considerable damage.
They are quite disagreeable, aren't they... shall we have a go at them?
Delighted.
We shall thrash them.
En garde.
Stop it. Put that down.
Your sword, sir...
I don't have a sword.
How do expect to fight without your sword?
I don't expect to fight.
Do I detect a streak of yellow along the good fellow's back?
Perhaps we can supply a more appropriate adversary for him. Number One...
Number One...
Am I late? Did I miss the fight?
En garde... (looks closely at Riker, reacts) Sir... you have a familiar bearing... is it possible we have crossed swords somewhere before?
Where is he? Where is Barclay?
Ah, a personal grudge. I warn you... you would be wise to put your affairs in final order before you meet him in combat. You challenge the greatest sword in all the...
... in all the Holodeck.
You think this is funny?
You are very tall. It could be very threatening to some people.
Barclay'll find out what it means to be threatened. Computer, discontinue image of Riker.
Sir, you have no sense of fair play.
Just tell us where to find Barclay.
You're gonna make us search through this to find him?
It could provide us with valuable information about what's troubling him.
There's nothing wrong with a healthy fantasy life, as long as it doesn't take over.
You call this healthy?
You're taking it so seriously. This is not without its element of humor...
I am the Goddess of Empathy! Cast off your inhibitions and embrace love, truth, joy...
Oh my God...
Discard your facades and reveal your true being to me.
Computer, discontinue --
Belay that order, computer! We want to get more insight into what's troubling the poor man. Remember? Quite a healthy fantasy life, wouldn't you agree?
Report...
Sir, our velocity increased to warp seven point two five.
Compensating, sir.
Confirmed. Velocity now warp seven.
Maintain that. What the hell happened?
The matter/anti-matter injectors locked for a split second, Captain. I am not certain why. They seem to be working properly now.
Picard to La Forge.
Go ahead, Captain.
Any explanation for the injector problem?
I'm not in Engineering, sir. I'm in Holodeck Two.
Another malfunction?
Not exactly, sir. I'll return to Engineering immediately.
Yes, I would say you should, Commander. Your Holodeck activities can wait until later. And Commander...
Yessir?
It would be wise to consult Lieutenant Barclay on this latest incident.
I'd like to, very much, sir. La Forge out. END INTERCUT:
We need to find Barclay. Now.
Cast aside your masks and let me slip into your minds...
Muzzle it.
Shhhhh!
We have a lot to talk about.
Sir, Barclay and I better get to Engineering.
Dismissed.
I just couldn't keep my eyes open... I'd worked twelve hours on the power systems and then the transporter went down and...
Reg... you had a chance to get some help from the real Counselor Troi... but instead you went back in there...
I know... I didn't want to... I just couldn't help myself...
You're gonna be able to write the book on holodiction. Look, I know how easy it is to get caught up in it. I... fell in love in there once.
Really?
But I knew when it was time to turn it off and say goodbye... Wasn't easy. But I did it.
You know... the people I create in there have started to become more real to me... than anyone out here. Except maybe for you, Commander.
I need you out here, Reg... right now, more than ever.
The injectors aren't responding to the diagnostic commands.
I... think we should drop out of warp.
La Forge to bridge.
Go ahead, Commander.
Recommend we go to impulse power sir.
Take us out of warp.
Controls are not responding, Captain.
It's the injectors.
Override.
It's not a computer problem. The mechanism is physically jammed. I can't clear it.
Speed increasing, Captain. Warp seven point six... seven point six five... seven point seven...
We can't shut it down, Captain. The anti-matter flow is increasing. She's accelerating out of control.
Approaching warp nine sir...
Red Alert.
Data, estimated time to structural failure.
At this rate of acceleration, fifteen minutes, forty seconds, Commander...
Geordi, did you copy?
Aye, Commander...
Recommendations.
I'll let you know as soon as we have some. La Forge out.
Okay, this ship will start tearing itself apart in fifteen minutes... I want every idea on the table... I don't care how outrageous...
What about attempting a magnetic quench on the fusion pre-burners?
No, I tried that already... the magnetic fields won't reset.
Could the fuel inlet servos be caught in cycle?
If they were, the swirl dampers would be frozen too... and they aren't...
Nothing showed up in the diagnostic sweep... at all?
The tests... uh, showed problems... I mean no problems with the flow... the flow of the...
There's nothing wrong with the computer control protocols or the power transfer systems. As far as we can determine, the injectors are just physically jammed...
Injectors freeze... antigrav unit goes down... transporter malfunctions...
And a twisted glass...
What's the connection?
Exceeding warp nine point four.
Begin evacuation of secondary hull. Prepare for emergency saucer separation.
Standing by to release docking clamps.
Re-route systems to primary hull power sources.
Captain, the plasma flow to the nacelles is uneven due to the injector lock. An emergency saucer separation could rupture the warp field.
Twelve minutes to structural failure.
None of the systems involved interact directly with each other... I don't see anything in common...
What if... what if... what if one of us is the connection?
Us? How?

I don't know. But we're looking for... a, a systemic explanation and there isn't one. We work with all the systems that are affected ... what if we're transmitting something ourselves... by touching it, or something...
The computer sensors would've picked up anything dangerous.
But... if it were something... something that we couldn't scan... You might've passed it to the injectors when you were realigning the magnetic capacitors.
It was your glass, Duffy... and both of you were in the cargo bay when the anti-grav failed...
So was O'Brien.
The transporter malfunction. That's a connection too.
Danger. Approaching safety limits of engine containment field.
Computer, list all physical substances that wouldn't normally be picked up by internal scans.
There are fifteen thousand five hundred twenty-five known substances that cannot be detected by standard scans.
Great. How many of those can exist in an oxygen atmosphere?
Five hundred thirty-two.
And could alter molecular structure when it comes in contact with... ... with glass.
Five.
(touches pool table button) On screen at this station.
Jakmanite has a half life of about fifteen seconds. There wouldn't be enough time to spread it around the ship.
Right.
Selgninaem and Lucrovexitrin are extremely toxic.
(acknowledges, touches panel again) We'd all be dead by now. That leaves Saltzgadum and Invidium. Neither of which has been used for decades.
Could either one be causing all these malfunctions?
Most of the affected systems weren't even invented when those substances were in use. Who knows what they could do to a transporter or a magnetic capacitor... ?
Wasn't Invidium used in... medical containment fields?
Not for over a century.
But the Mikulaks might still be using it.
And one of those canisters was broken.
La Forge to bridge. We have a working theory, Captain...
There's a chance we picked up some Invidium from a broken canister in the cargo bay... and have been spreading it around the ship...
Working theories are fine, Geordi. But we need a working solution in about five minutes...
Understood, Commander. We're on our way to Cargo Bay Five for confirmation.
Nothing from the tricorder...
Danger. Exceeding safety limits of engine containment field. At current acceleration, structural failure will occur in three minutes, thirty seconds.
There it is...
Duffy and O'Brien picked up the broken canister and became contaminated..
If we can get it... the invidium... down to minus two hundred degrees Celsius, it'll become inert.
La Forge to bridge. Invidium is confirmed.
Recommend we flood the injector pathway conduit with liquid nitrogen. That should neutralize it.
The question is, will the injectors come back on-line?
The injectors have sustained considerable damage, sir. I can't guarantee we'll be able to regain control...
We don't have much choice, do we?
Nossir.
Make it so.
Route primary coupling through starboard transfer conduit.
Routing... ready for engine core injection.
At current acceleration, structural failure will occur in forty-five seconds.
Injector conduit temperature minus one hundred degrees Celsius.
Transfer injector control to manual.
Ready... temperature now minus one hundred ninety degrees... minus two hundred degrees, sir.
Injector status?
Matter injector... is on-line. Anti-matter injector... still locked.
At current acceleration, structural failure will occur in thirty seconds.
Cycle power through ventral relay.
Anti-matter injector... on-line. Reducing flow capacity. Commencing warp engine shut-down.
Stand down from Red Alert.
Nice work, Geordi.
Mister Barclay and I thank you, sir.
Acknowledged.
The ship is seriously contaminated with Invidium, sir. Recommend we set course for Starbase one-two-one for a complete systems and bio-decontamination.
Understood.
Glad you were with us out here in the real world today, Mister Barclay.

It has been most difficult to reach this decision to leave you... but after thinking it over, discussing it at length with Counselor Troi... I think it is for the best... I just wanted to thank you all for your support...
You'll always be welcome here, Barclay.
I know. That's what makes it hard to go.
It was a pleasure to serve with you, Mister Barclay.
Good luck, Reg.
It's been fun. Computer, end program.
Erase all programs filed under Reginald Barclay.
Except... Program Nine...
Captain's log, Stardate 43779.3. The Enterprise is preparing detailed atmospheric charts of the Hayashi system. Although tedious, this endeavor is the first step toward planet colonization.
Sensors report the USS Hood closing on an intercept course at high warp.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: That's odd... I wasn't notified of a rendezvous.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: They seem to be in an awful hurry.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Sir, we are being hailed on a secured channel by Captain DeSoto.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: On screen.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Sorry to sneak up on you like that, Jean-Luc --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Robert, why didn't you inform us --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: -- Out here, you never know who's listening. Keeps you on your toes, anyway. Hey, Will, you getting soft on that luxury liner?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: So, old friend. How are you?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Ah, you know, they send you Galaxy-Class boys out here to the far reaches. Me, I'm hauling my butt back and forth between starbases --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: But not today.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Nope. Starfleet's got new orders for you. This is top priority. They need the fastest ship in the fleet -- and the best people. That's you.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: If time is so important, why didn't they transmit the orders by subspace?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: They're worried about Romulan eavesdropping on this one. And we've got a passenger for you. Hard to send by subspace.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: What sort of passenger?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Mission specialist. He'll bring your orders aboard with him. Name's Tam Elbrun.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Elbrun? You mean Tam Elbrun as in the Ghorusda disaster?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: The same. What can I say? Your orders are to cooperate fully with him.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Best of luck, folks. Hood out.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Sir, the Hood is slowing to impulse.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Mister Data, come with me --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Captain, let me come with you to greet Tam --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: You know him?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: I do... He was at the university on Betazed when I studied psychology there.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Ah, I see. He was a colleague, then.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: No, sir. He was a patient...
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Tam is a telepath of extraordinary talent, even for a Betazoid. He's a specialist in first contact with new life-forms, and... a rather unique person. He's not what you might expect, Captain.
scene: 14   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - PICARD, TROI AND DATA

quote: Welcome aboard the Enterprise. I'm --
Captain Picard. Here --
You want to know all about your mission. Everything's on there. Orders and briefings. Destination and heading, all that.
I sensed you were out here. How've you been?
(embarrassed by Tam's tactlessness, she still can't help smiling) Fine, but Tam, I...
Sir --
Who -- what are you?
My name is Data.
Incredible, an android. I can't read you at all. It's like you're not there.
Oh. You better hurry up to the bridge with that. Captain wants you to run the orders, scan the technical schematics, and be ready to brief him in ten minutes. Right?
Number One?
Riker here.
Meet Mister Data on the bridge. He has our orders and new heading.
Aye, sir.
And assemble the bridge staff for a mission briefing in -- fifteen minutes. Picard out. Mister Elbrun. Would you --
Like to see my quarters. No. I'd rather get this briefing over with. Then be left alone until I'm needed.
I've heard something about Ghorusda. Weren't about forty people killed --
scene: 19   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - RIKER AND GEORDI

quote: Forty-seven, including the captain of the Adelphi -- and two friends from my class at the Academy.
scene: 19   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - RIKER AND GEORDI

quote: Sorry. What happened?
scene: 19   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - RIKER AND GEORDI

quote: It was a first contact situation.
The Ghorusdans values are so complex, and so different, that the Federation sent along a specialist. To prevent misunderstanding.
That was Tam Elbrun? And what happened was his fault?

Not directly. Board of inquiry blamed Captain Darson's carelessness about Ghorusdan cultural taboos. But if Elbrun's so good, why didn't he warn Darson? What was he there for, if he couldn't sense that much hostility?
Commander, Geordi... do you ever feel as if I am not "there?" That is to say... not "here."
You seem to be all here.
Our destination is the Beta Stromgren system, following the path of the Vega Nine probe.
That's twenty-three parsecs beyond our furthest manned explorations.
That is correct, Commander. Apparently the probe has discovered... (a beat, reacting to something he sees on the screen) ...Astonishing.
This is the star Beta Stromgren...

Scientists have discovered that it is in the final stages of an alternating cycle of expansion and collapse, which will soon result in a supernova. However, the long-range unmanned probe which Starfleet sent to observe the process has discovered something much more --
Oh, Data -- don't waste time.
